user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_apply_params:
```c
static int
check_apply_params (void)
{
  if (tool_params.help)
  {
    show_help ();
    return -1;
  }
  else if (tool_params.version)
  {
    print_version ();
    return -1;
  }
  check_param_port ();
  check_apply_param__all_cpus ();
  check_apply_param__threads ();
  if (! check_apply_param__thread_per_conn ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  if (! check_param__epoll ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  if (! check_param__poll ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  check_param__empty_tiny_medium_large ();
  check_param__shared_single_unique ();
  if (! check_param__connections ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No pointer types are used in the provided code fragment. The function contains only: structure-member accesses via the dot operator (tool_params.help and tool_params.version), calls to other functions, integer/boolean conditionals, and integer return values. There are no pointer declarations, no address-of (&) or dereference (*) operators, and no use of the arrow operator (->) that would indicate a pointer to a struct. Therefore, within this fragment there are no pointer objects that could be made to point to const-qualified types and nothing that directly triggers Rule 8.13. Note: the called functions and other code outside this fragment might use pointers and should be reviewed separately, but they are not part of the given code and thus are not reported here.
